comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
New York state senator A. J. Palmer, of Ulster, N. Y., was a member of the Progressive Party, and a sponsor of reform legislation. In April, 1913, he introduced a bill in the N. Y. legislature to repeal public utility franchises of all types after a term of twenty-five years. In March, 1914 he was quoted in a New York Times story on the necessity of paying legislators an adequate wage, as a means of removing money from politics. Here is another Bain/LOC portrait of Senator Palmer:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3931069525/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I added his to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._J._Palmer [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3931069525/in/photostream/] Abraham John Palmer, M.D., (1847 - April 17, 1922) was a physician and a Methodist minister, and a member of the New York Legislature from Ulster, New York who was a member of Theodore Roosevelt's Progressive Party.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks to both of you for the further information on A. J. Palmer.  We'll incorporate more identification information when we next update the description.
